Name: da huang
大黃
Biological: Rheum palmatum Linn (zhang ye da huang 掌葉大黃)
Rheum tanguticum Maxim. et Baill. (tang gu te da huang 唐古特大黄)
Rheum officinale Baill. (yao yong da huang 药用大黄)
Other name: zhi jun (prepared da huang) 制軍（制大黄）

Geography: Rheum palmatum Linn (zhang ye da huang 掌葉大黃): Sichuan, Gansu, Qinghai, Xikang and other provinces.
Rheum tanguticum Maxim. et Baill. (tang gu te da huang 唐古特大黄): Sichuan, Gansu, Qinghai and other provinces.
Rheum officinale Baill. (yao yong da huang 药用大黄): Hubei, Sichuan, Guizhou, Yunnan and other provinces.
Maladies Treated: Losing large amount of blood (therapeutic effect)
Sudden stoppage of heart or respiration (therapeutic effect)
Inflammation of the stomach (intestinal paralysis and liver cell injury in acute hepatitis, and acute lung injury, as prevention)
Medical Function: Induces diarrhea: Oral administration of water or an alcohol extract created diarrhea in white lab mice. Its water extract did not affect the carbon powder movement in the small intestine, but could promote the expelling of the carbon powder. It did not affect the amount of water in the small intestine but increased the water in the large intestine. Using the extract for muscle or vein injection did not induce diarrhea. The laxative effect of da huang has nothing to do with the blood flow but is a direct effect in the large intestine, causing the large intestine's motility, and an increase in the amount of moisture generated, thus causing the purgative effect.
Lowers blood urea nitrogen (BUN) in the blood: The rhatannin component by intraperitoneal injection in rabbits can lower blood BUN.
Anti-bacteria.
Anti-virus: Water extract possesses anti-virus effect; anti HBV.
Samples of Formulae:
xiao cheng qi tang (小承氣湯), tao he cheng qi tang (桃核承氣湯), da huang mu dan pi tang (大黃牡丹皮湯), da huang gan cao tang (大黃甘草湯), da huang zhe chong wan (大黃蟅蟲丸), da cheng qi tang (大承氣湯).

Note: Cooking for more than 10 minutes will reduce its purgative effect. For purgative effect, use raw da huang. For blood invigorating action use wine or vinegar treated da huang. To stop bleeding, use charred da huang.
Contraindications:
Not suitable for patients with pixu (spleen deficient) condition. Long term usage is not recommended. Constipation may follow after sudden dropping of usage of da huang after long period of time.

Not suitable for those with spleen deficiency or stomach cold. According to the Chinese Herb Lexicon (《中藥辭海》), da huang contains a large amount of tannin; therefore, small doses not only do not cause a laxative effect, but have an astringent effect; after stopping the drug, secondary constipation often appears. Contains oxalic acid, which is toxic when used in large doses.
Research: Da huang can inhibit Coxsackie virus B3. Researchers at the medical school of Wuhan University of China announced that researchers Zhan-Qiu Yang et al. of their Virus Research Unit verified that although da huang cannot directly kill CVB3, it can induce the cells of CVB3 to shrink, peel off, and break; thus it can stop CVB3 from multiplying. This inhibits CVB3 replication, depriving it of virulence and exerting da huang's antiviral effect, thus proving that traditional Chinese medicine da huang has a cytopathic inhibitory effect on Coxsackie virus B3.
Notes:
Authentic medicinal plants of da huang are the dried roots and rhizomes of Rheum palmatum L., Rheum tanguticum Maxim. ex Balf., or Rheum officinale Baill. Their physical identifying characteristics are: rhizome diameter is about 3 ~ 10 cm. The medulla portions of new cross-sections are broad, with design of star points ringing out or scattered.

Identification of authentic da huang: Take the product powder 0.2 g, add 2 ml of warm methanol. Soak for 10 minutes, let cool. Take the 10 μl of supernatant and drop a dot on filter paper. Drop a drop of 45% ethanol on it. Remove the paper, let it dry and stand for 10 minutes. Review under UV light (365nm), should not show significant lasting bright purple fluorescent. (check Rumex II).

Counterfeit da huang (as explained by Shen Bao-An):
- Rheum franzenbachii Munt: root diameter is about 1 ~ 5 cm; cross-section without star points and shows purple fluorescence in the UV lamp.
- Rheum hotaoense C. Y. Cheng et C. T. Kao: root diameter is about 1.5 ~ 4 cm; no star points on the cross-section and shows purple fluorescence in the UV lamp.
- Rheum emodi Wall.: root diameter is about 1 ~ 5 cm; new cross-section in the sunlight shows significant blue-gray, and shows violet fluorescence in the ultraviolet lamp.
- Rheum wittrochii Lundstr.: root diameter is about 2.5 ~ 4 cm; no star points on the cross-section and shows purple fluorescence in the UV lamp.

Name: qing xiang zi
ji guan hua
Biological: Celosia argentea L. (qing xiang zi 青葙)
Celosia cristata L. (ji guan hua 雞冠花)
Other name: qing xiang hua also called: ye ji guan hua, gou wei hua, gou wei xian
ji guan hua also called: ji gong hua, ji jie hua, ji jiao hua

Geography: Ji guan hua (Celosia cristata L.) was originally growing in Africa, South America and India. Now it is grown throughout China and Southeast Asia.
Qing xiang hua (Celosia argentea L.) is found in whole China and Southeast Asia.
Maladies Treated: Qing xiang zi decoction used as drops stops nose bleeding
Internal use in heat, painful, swollen eyes, superficial visual obstruction and cataracts caused by wind-heat or liver fire
Ji guan hua zi: bleeding in hemorrhoids
Diarrhea with red and white mucus
Yeast infections with red or white discharge
Medical Function: Anti-inflammation
Dilates blood vessels

Killing effect of Trichomonas vaginalis: Celosia decoction possesses a good killing effect on human Trichomonas vaginalis. Using 10% decoction of Trichomonas vaginalis with same amount culture medium, in 30 minutes the parasites became round, activities were decreased, and in 60 minutes most of the parasites disappeared. With 20% decoction, the parasites disappeared within 5-10 minutes.
Using 10% celosia injections on pregnant rats, pregnant guinea pigs, and rabbits resulted in mid-term induction abortion.
Dosage: Per day dosage: seed or flower, 5~10 grams.
Samples of Formulae: 淋渫雞冠散: For the treatment of five hemorrhoids, swelling and pain around the anus, or protruding to the breast, or protruding to other places, sores that do not heal for a long time and turn into fistulas: Ji guan hua (Celosia cristata flower) and feng yan cao (Wind-eye grass) each one liang (approx. 30 grams). Grind into coarse powder. Each time, use half a liang of powder, add half a bowl of water, boil three to five times, wash the affected area while hot. (From Wei Sheng Bao Jian [Precious Mirror of Health]).
Contraindications:
Do not use in cases of glaucoma or liver or kidney deficiency because it has a strong heat clearing effect and can dilate the pupils.
青光眼﹐瞳孔散大或肝弱或腎虛者忌用
Notes: Ji guan hua (Celosia cristata L.) and qing xiang (Celosia argentea L.) are of the same family but different species. The flowers with the shape of the comb of male chicken are called ji guan hua, literally meaning chicken comb flower. The flowers with the shape of wheat sprays are called qing xiang. 'Zi' means seed. They can be used interchangeably.
References:
[1] Zhong Hua Ben Cao
[1] 中華本草
